subsection.title: The Distance Formula
subsection.p: Delbert is hiking in the Santa Monica mountains, and he would like to know the distance from the Sycamore Canyon trail head, located at 12-C on his map, to the Coyote Trail junction, located at 8-F, as shown below.

Each interval on the map represents one kilometer. Delbert remembers the Pythagorean theorem, and uses the map coordinates to label the sides of a right triangle. The distance he wants is the hypotenuse of the triangle, so
The straight-line distance to Coyote junction is about 5 kilometers.
The formula for the distance between two points is obtained in the same way.

sidebyside.p: We first label a right triangle with points P_{1} and P_{2} on opposite ends of the hypotenuse. (See the figure at right.) The sides of the triangle have lengths \abs{x_2-x_1} and \abs{y_2-y_1}. We can use the Pythagorean theorem to calculate the distance between P_{1} and P_{2}: d^2=(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2

subsection.p: Taking the (positive) square root of each side of this equation gives us the distance formula.

assemblage.title: Distance Formula
assemblage.p: The distance d between two points P_{1}(x_1, y_1) and P_{2}(x_2, y_2) is d=\sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2+(y_2-y_1)^2}

subsection.title: Equation for a Circle
subsection.p: A circle is the set of all points in a plane that lie at a given distance, called the radius, from a fixed point called the center. We can use the distance formula to find an equation for a circle.

sidebyside.p: The circle shown at right has its center at the origin, (0,0), and its radius is r. Now, the distance from the origin to any point P(x,y) on the circle is r. Therefore, \sqrt{(x-0)^2+(y-0)^2} = r or, squaring both sides, (x-0)^2+(y-0)^2=r^2

subsection.p: Because every point on the circle must satisfy this equation, we have found an equation for the circle.

assemblage.title: Circle
assemblage.p: The equation for a circle of radius r centered at the origin is x^2+y^2=r^2

subsection.p: The circle in the exercise above, x^2+y^2=1, which is centered at the origin and has radius 1 unit, is called the unit circle.

subsection.title: Rational and Irrational Numbers
subsection.p: Every common fraction, such as \dfrac{3}{4}, can be written in many equivalent forms, including a decimal form. For example, \frac{3}{4}=\frac{6}{8}=\frac{75}{100}=0.75~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~\frac{5}{11}=\frac{20}{44}=\frac{50}{110}=0.\overline{45}
where 0.\overline{45} is the repeating decimal 0.45454545....
Because the fraction bar denotes division, a fraction is a quotient of two integers, and we can calculate its decimal form by dividing the denominator into the numerator.

Any number (including fractions) that can be written as a quotient of two integers ~~\dfrac{a}{b},~~\text{where}~~ b\not=0,~~ is called a rational number. The decimal form of a rational number is either a terminating decimal, such as 0.75, or a repeating decimal, such as 0.\overline{45}. Thus, we can always write down an exact decimal equivalent for a rational number, although we may choose to round off a particularly long or unwieldy decimal. For example, \frac{3}{7}=0.\overline{428571}\approx 0.43

warning.p: Note that 0.43 is not exactly equal to \dfrac{3}{7}; it is an approximation for \dfrac{3}{7}, just as 0.33 is an approximation for \dfrac{1}{3}. In our work, it will be important to distinguish between exact values and approximations.

subsection.p: but none of these decimal forms ever ends. Thus, we cannot write down an exact decimal equivalent for an irrational number. The best we can do is give a decimal approximation, no matter how many digits we include.

statement.p: Which values are exact, and which are approximations?

Because 8 is not a perfect square, \sqrt{8} is irrational, so 2.828427125 is not the exact value of \sqrt{8}.
\sqrt{0.16}=\sqrt{\dfrac{16}{100}}=\dfrac{4}{10}=0.4, so this value is exact.
Because \dfrac{\pi}{2} is an irrational number, it has no decimal equivalent, so 1.570796327 is an approximation.

subsection.title: Circumference and Area
subsection.p: Recall from geometry that the circumference of a circle is proportional to its radius.

assemblage.title: Circumference of a Circle
assemblage.p: The circumference of a circle of radius r is given by C=2\pi r

subsection.p: The number \pi gives the ratio of the circumference of any circle to its diameter. It is an irrational number, \pi\approx 3.14159.
The length of a portion, or arc, of a circle, is called its arclength.

statement.p: Francine baked an apple pie with diameter 8 inches. If Delbert cuts himself a 60째 wedge, what is the arclength of the curved edge?

solution.p: Using a calculator, we find that \dfrac{4\pi}{3}=4.19 rounded to two decimal places, so the length of the curved edge is between 4 and 4 \frac{1}{2} inches.

subsection.p: The area of a circle is proportional to the square of its radius.

assemblage.title: Area of a Circle
assemblage.p: The area of a circle of radius r is given by A=2\pi r^2

subsection.p: A portion of a circle shaped like a pie-shaped wedge is called a sector.

statement.p: What is the area of Delbert's slice of apple pie in the previous example?

The area of the wedge is \dfrac{8\pi}{3}, or about 8.34 square inches.
